Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Photoprotection for Tolerance to Abiotic Stress: Discovery through Natural Genetic Variation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Photosynthesis, the fundamental biochemical process sustaining life in this planet, requires light energy. Any environmental stress such as cold, drought or heat will limit the amount of fixed CO2, and trigger photoprotection mechanisms to dissipate or avoid absorption of excess energy that might cause damage to cells and the plant as a whole. The physiological and genetic aspects of photoprotection have been studied in model species but there has been no investigation of photoprotection as a useful and improvable mechanism of abiotic stress tolerance in crop species. Considering that abiotic stresses are the main cause of yield loss in agricultural systems, and that climate change will generate even more extreme environmental conditions, the utilization of a novel abiotic stress mechanism such as photoprotection could have a significant impact on crop productivity and thus on the prosperity of our society. The goal of this project is to discover genes/molecular markers affecting the plant's capacity to cope with excessive energy under stress conditions, using natural genetic variation in sorghum, a commercially important crop. This project includes the following specific aims: 1) to determine the drought and cold experimental conditions that would maximize the photoprotection response; 2) to test the association of photoprotection candidate genes with photosynthesis and fluorescence by Linkage Disequilibrium (LD) mapping; 3) to discover novel genes/markers associated with variation in photoprotection; and 4) to identify candidate genes, functional polymorphisms and determine expression levels of allelic variants associated with higher photoprotective capacity under stress.

The outcomes of this project include genes/markers and allelic variants associated with superior photoprotective capacity, the functional polymorphisms and expression profiles of those genes, and molecular markers that could be tested under multiple environmental conditions and exploited in breeding programs. The project will also provide research training and mentoring for one PhD and one undergraduate student. With regard to outreach to the general public, the project will develop a new module for Meta!Blast, a real-time 3D action-adventure video game designed to engage students in the learning process of complex biological systems. "Photoprotection" complements current modules and will focus on photoprotection and its effects on society. This game will be utilized by high school teachers in biology courses but also in undergraduate courses at Iowa State University (ISU). In addition, the project will provide demonstrations and extension presentations at the biannual Iowa Farm Progress Show and the ISU Research and Demonstration Farms, respectively. These opportunities to disseminate knowledge generated in this project to the general public are uniquely valuable because of the number of people attending those events, their roles on agricultural production systems and therefore their impact on society. All germplasms used in this project are freely available through the USDA-ARS National Genetic Resources Preservation (NCGRP). All sequence data will be deposited in the NCBI GenBank dbSNP and GSS databases. All phenotypic data will be deposited long-term at the USDA-ARS Germplasm Resources Information Network (GRIN) (http://www.ars-grin.gov/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photosynthesis is the fundamental biochemical process sustaining life in this planet in which light energy is utilized to fix CO2. Any environmental stress, such as cold, drought or heat, will limit the amount of fixed CO2 and thus, light energy must be either not absorbed or dissipated after absorption to avoid damage to cells and the plant as a whole. The mechanisms involved in protecting plants from damaging light levels are generally called photoprotection but have not been exploited as useful and improvable mechanisms of abiotic stress tolerance in economically important crops.

Tolerance to abiotic stress is one of the most important characteristics affecting crop yield but is also among the most difficult traits to be genetically improved. The challenges for genetic improvement of tolerance to abiotic stresses will only increase in light of the environmental conditions associated with climate change. Therefore, the long term goal of this project was to utilize photoprotection as a novel mechanism of abiotic stress tolerance though breeding, genetic transformation or gene editing. The specific objectives of this proposal included the discovery of genes/chromosomal regions controlling the plant’s capacity to cope with excessive energy under cold and drought stress conditions, using natural genetic variation in sorghum, a commercially important crop.

This project, performed at one of the largest scales up to date using natural genetic variation, has generated the first evidence of the complex genetic architecture controlling photosynthesis under non-stress, cold stress and drought stress conditions in sorghum. A set of candidate genes were identified for further investigation including antioxidants, components of photosystem I, phytohormones and thioredoxin, among others. Some of these candidate genes were initially tested and preliminary evidence confirms their role in carbon fixation or stress response. This new knowledge constitutes the foundation for additional studies to clone genes controlling the photoprotection response to abiotic stress. This novel mechanism of abiotic stress tolerance can be manipulated not only in sorghum but also for the genetic improvement of other commercially important crops. Therefore, these discoveries are highly relevant to agriculture in the United States, to the production of food, feed, fiber and fuel, and thus, to the general society.

As a CAREER project, this grant was also focused on the development of educational tools and training opportunities that were integrated with the research objectives. A new 3D Meta!blast videogame module was developed to help students learn about photoprotection and the photosynthetic response to abiotic stress. This module has three levels of difficulty and is targeted both to high school and early undergraduate students. The implementation of virtual reality tools in education programs is targeted to give students a feel for the excitement and complexity of plant responses to light stress. Finally, this grant provided opportunities for education and professional development of several students and personnel of underrepresented minority groups.
